conclusion: The magnetic force exerted on the horizontal side of the coil in the field is F = n I L B.
With the original current direction, the force acts upward or downward depending on the connection.
When the current is reversed, the force reverses as well, changing direction by 180°.
The force on the right arm changes from +F to –F, resulting in a net change of ΔF = 2 F = 2 n I L B.
To restore equilibrium after reversal, a mass m is placed in the left pan, producing an additional downward force mg.
Equilibrium requires the added gravitational force to match the change in magnetic force: mg = 2 n I L B.
Solving for B gives B = mg / (2 n I L).
The magnitude of the magnetic–induction intensity is B = mg / (2 n I L).
